6:28 Critical pressure is NOT the pressure at which a substance remains a liquid regardless of temperature.  There is no such pressure, as we can always exceed the critical temperature and create either a gas or supercritical fluid.  Critical pressure is the pressure at which a substance remains liquid at the critical temperature.  The (x,y) coordinates of the critical point are (critical temperature, critical pressure.)

At 4:50, Shini claims that at higher pressures, real gases tend to have a bit less volume than ideal gases.  This is incorrect.  The compression violates the assumption that the molecules have no inherent volume, so the real gases have MORE volume than the ideal prediction.  She's right about the too cold situation.  It's interesting that the direction of the deviation from the ideal depends on whether it's too tight or too cold!

Even though I have 3 College Degrees that I earned 40+ years ago they were not in the Sciences.  My son has advanced degrees in Engineering/Physics/Electrical Engineering.  My daughter is a Math Teacher in a rural Elementary School.  I never even took Physics at all.  Over 90% of American adults have never taken any advanced Mathematics OR Basic Physics.  Even when explained at an elementary level most Americans don't have the Mathematics background to understand even this video.  I wish I had taken hard sciences and mathematics in my "College Days".  That is why this video has so few viewers, sadly...

How many entities (molecules, particles, whatever) are required for phase changes to be a thing?  I am asking in the most generic sense possible, not in the specific case of the 'phases of matter' being described in this video (which, BTW, why did Bose-Einstein condensates and plasmas not even get a mention?).  Phase change seems to be one of the only general concepts which can apply across all complex systems, but it seems to not be terribly rigorously defined.  Obviously you can't have it with 1 entity, as it is an emergent property of interactions, but can you have it with 2?  Can 2 molecules of water be a 'solid'?  Or do you need more?  How many?  And why?

In general, this is great... but please, slow down a bit. :) Especially when reading formulae. Also, please back up calculations like the one starting at 3:10 with a visual aid. I get the 300 K, but even though I'm quite proficient in English (which is not my native language), I completely black out at the number that follows, which means that while I still try to process this number, I'm not focused on the equations that follow, so I miss a good deal of those as well, and so on. It's on screen later on (from 3:36) - for about two seconds, so I almost certainly have to rewind because I missed the opportunity to pause the video while it's there. Even though I liked the math-y parts of physics, and have no problems understanding the calculations in principle, and know English well enough to understand these videos, the rapid-fire delivery makes it unnecessary hard to watch them. But generally: please keep doing them. :)

Commenters on this series have frequently complained that the material is too advanced.  This is disappointing to me since the level of the material is the same as standard high school physics with a bit of calculus added, and since the series got into gases, a bit of high school chemistry.  I wonder if another attempt might be made, introducing physics through the common laboratory experiments used in high school and college classes?  The first experiment in my high school physics class studied the acceleration of a falling weight using distance vs time.  It is pretty real when you measure the distance intervals on a paper tape using a meter stick, and plot them to find a nearly perfect parabola.

It becomes "supercritical". Basically the words "liquid" and "gas" lose their meaning and you're left with this weird soupy mist. There are lots of videos of supercritical CO2 on youtube.

basically it bec0mes a mix 0f b0th liquid and gas...   if y0u were t0 l00k at each m0lecule 0ne at a time... they w0uld be in different phases at different times depending 0n the exact l0cal c0nditi0ns f0r a given time... but change w0uld be king

+calholli  I think "mixture of liquid and gas" is misleading.  In the supercritical region, the density and properties that depend on density can, if you are in the right part of the diagram, be near those of the liquid phase, but the viscosity and diffusivity are more like the gas phase.  It's not all one thing, either, as the properties vary continuously all over the supercritical range.  You can be more liquid like or more gas like or in between.  The one thing you can not have, in a simple system, is any mixture of liquid and gas.

Dennis Haupt   It is important to counter flat-earthers and other public liars.  We may not convince them, but we may slow the spread of their lies.  Impressionable people see their lies and may think the lies are true, unless someone tells the truth.  There is another reason.  So long as honest people counter flat-earthers and other public liars, they know they are lying.  That is important.  When people begin to believe their own lies, they become dangerous.

Dennis Haupt   I see ISS pass over my home quite easily with nothing other than my middle-aged eyes.  I saw one or both of the Echo satellites back in the early 1960's the same way, with much younger eyes.  I have seen other satellites, too, with no telescope or binoculars.  They are not hard to see.  You only need to know when and where to look, or in the case of random satellites, a dark sky and an hour or two spent lying on your back, looking up in the couple of hours after sunset or before dawn.  You can get email announcements when ISS will be visible over your location at:    https://spotthestation.nasa.gov/signup.cfm   Predictions for other satellites can be found here:   http://www.heavens-above.com
Mark Holm You could easily explain the visible path of satellites by claiming they are ballistic.
Joshua Pearce   What do you mean by "ballistic", Mr Pearce?
Dennis Haupt Then as a crazy person who knows better than scientists, I would just claim they're rocket powered, or aircraft.

Joshua Pearce   If by "rocket powered or aircraft" you mean a vehicle traveling through an atmosphere above a flat earth, then you would have an easily measured discrepancy between the apparent motion of satellites around a (nearly) spherical earth and the motion of your flat earth air vehicles.  Start drawing the triangles, and you see that, away from the zenith, the two geometries make quite different predictions.

Dennis Haupt Mr Haupt's point about launch and impact points has even broader implications.  For instance, it is well known that satellites in general and the ISS in particular are easily observed from many places on Earth on a regular and predictable schedule.  Further, the apparent path in the sky, for one location, changes from apparition to apparition.  Sometimes it comes from the northwest, sometimes from the southwest.  In order for cannon ball like projectiles, that are launched and quickly crash, to replicate this behavior, there would have to be multiple launch and crash sites, and of course, there would have to be multiple launches on a rather short time scale.  And there are the geosynchronous satellites, which in a flat earth view, would be completely motionless and would, presumably fall quickly to Earth.  And if you don't believe in geosynchronous satellites, then answer me why so many people have antennas mounted on their houses pointing to the sky, for which they pay a great deal of money in order to follow the lives of the Kardashians.  If the Kardashians are not coming from geosynchronous satellites, then why can an antenna staring at the sky receive them, whereas, if it is aimed elsewhere, it does not receive them?  In fact, satellite TV is famous for bringing the Kardashians to remote locations where no other Kardashian transmitting technology has yet penetrated.

Mark Holm You're relying on complicated math to prove an idiot wrong. If this brand of idiot could do the math, they wouldn't think the earth was flat to start with. You have to talk in their language (as limiting and crazy as it is).

Joshua Pearce   I am talking about simple geometric arguments involving easily observed properties of satellite orbits and, at most, a few triangles.  Yes, I am aware that the pseudoscience morons reject even 9th grade geometry, but it is useful to show that that is what they are doing.  It is good for people to know that their lies are easily exposed.
Mark Holm Their lies are far more easily exposed than that. All you have to do is go in an airplane and then pay attention. But they trust absolutely nothing that requires measurement.

My guess would be: find the composition of the atmosphere by looking at how it scatters light, then use what we know about our atmosphere and gases to predict how the pressure varies with height. Since then I'm sure they've made this more accurate with actual measurements from the probes, etc.
direct measurements I'd guess. Or maybe by using the mass of the planet and the height of the atmosphere to derive it. Or most likely both.

Both infrared light and microwaves are absorbed by various atmospheric gases.  We had an approximate idea of Mars atmospheric density before spacecraft ever went there, using Earth based telescopes.  The spacecraft enabled better measurements by putting a calibrated microwave transmitter in orbit around the planet, so that it could be observed from Earth.  Mariner 9 included both infrared and ultraviolet spectrometers.  Both of these instruments can contribute to atmospheric measurements.  Given that Mars atmosphere is largely carbon dioxide, the infrared spectrometer should have been particularly useful.
It's a liquid-gas...thing called a supercritical phase. The molecules are too energetic to settle into a liquid, but packed too tightly to spread out like a gas.

You have not described your hypothetical system well enough for any detailed analysis.  If you are describing a system in which you put in work of one kind and get out work of another kind, then the answer is a qualified yes.  You can transform one kind of work into another.  The catch is that there are both theoretical and practical limitations.  The theoretical limitation says that you can never get out as much work as you put in.  In fact, you usually lose a lot of your input work.  The practical limitations say you will always do worse even than theory allows.  The very best coal fired, steam power plants are below 50% overall efficiency.  Natural gas cogeneration plants can get into the high 50s.  That is about as well as you can do with a thermal power plant.  It is not for lack of knowledge or effort, the natural world makes those limits.

Work doesnt have  "kinds".... work simply means that an object is being given kinetic energy by some force.  I think you are conflating the terms work and energy.... you can transform one type of ENERGY into another and you can never get out as much energy as you put in, these statements however are meaningless with regard to "work".  Please understand the difference between work and energy before attempting to explain it.

+Ddub1083   Work is defined as the change in energy imparted to a system by a force working through a distance.  Work and energy have the same units, Joules.  In a reversible system, work and energy go back and forth, interchangeably, so that the distinction becomes meaningless.  With irreversible systems, you have to be very careful, accounting for entropy. Outside of physics class, it is conventional to talk about different types of work, as well as different types of energy.  Electrochemical energy and work, hydraulic energy and work, thermal energy and work, gravitational energy and work.  To a physicist, they are all force * distance.  Thermal and chemical systems have the additional confusion of entropy thrown in, but that does not enter into this discussion.

+Ddub1083   The system :Darko describes is an engine.  It produces work.  That is, it produces energy.  In this context, the output of an engine, we use the words work and energy synonymously.  The input to :Darko's engine appears to be gravitational work.  He is dropping rocks down a hole to heat water.  Once he has hot water, all the complications of thermodynamics apply.  Let's say the water expands to steam and he expands that in a steam engine to get mechanical work out.  At every stage where energy is transferred, there is work.  We can, and conventionally do label the work by the type of energy transfer involved.  Gravitational work, steam expansion work, mechanical work, electrical work, that is the way we conventionally discuss them, even though at their basic level, they are all force * distance and are all forms of energy.

:+:Darko  Actually, your system will be absurdly inefficient because all the energy you get out comes from dropping rocks down a hole, but before you can do that, you have to dig rocks out to make the hole.  You will use at least as much, and inevitably much more, energy digging the hole as you can maximally get out by dropping rocks back down the hole.  The only energy input to your system is the diesel fuel powering your hole digging machine.

+Ddub1083   I started off trying to give :Darko a reasonable answer to his question: was his device workable?  The question of the relationship of energy and work is not central to his question.  Regarding energy and work, consider this.  Is there such a thing as energy independent of work, or at least independent of the possibility of work?  In order to have work, something has to pass from higher energy to lower, and the work done on it is precisely equal to the energy difference. If you put it back, the energy is precisely returned.  If there were no energy gradient, there would be no work.  No work, no way to detect energy.  So without work, is there such a thing as energy?  Is work a manifestation of energy or is energy an invention to explain work?  And can you tell the difference between them?

"Is there such a thing as energy independent of work, or at least independent of the possibility of work? "  Yes... any energy that is exerted that does not result in kinetic energy IS NOT WORK. Work is simply how energy is transferred from one form to another... it is the process of transferring energy, it is not energy itself.  THEY ARE NOT EQUIVALENT.  (is that four times now ive had to state this?) "and the work done on it is precisely equal to the energy difference."  Again.... no.  You just keep exposing your lack of knowledge of the subject, I suggest you actually take the time to learn the distinction as ive REPEATEDLY told you.

+Ddub1083   It is clear we will have to agree to disagree on this one.  I define work as a noun, the result of a process that transfers energy, and thus synonymous with the energy transferred. You seem to define work as a verb, the action of transferring energy.  If we accelerate a mass from rest using a constant force, the work is f*d  and the kinetic energy is mv^2 , BUT  f*d = mv^2 .  The amount of work precisely equals the energy!  BTW, the link you gave is to material written for grade school students.
+Ddub1083   Read the Wikipedia article "Work".  It is clear, there, that work is defined as a noun and has been assigned the Joule as it's unit, the same unit as energy.

+Ddub1083   Energy transferred that does not result in kinetic energy is not work?  Tell that to Sisyphus.  I think you mean kinetic or potential energy.  In order to use up energy without doing work, you have to create entropy.  If you include entropy, you have to use deltaG = deltaH - T * delta S as your definition of Energy.  In the case of :Darko's engine, I was being charitable by assuming a reversible system: no entropy.  In an irreversible system, output energy (work) = input energy - heat loss - T*entropy gain.  Work in the irreversible case is still energy, it's just less energy than you put in.

iTuneTime   If you want to learn physics, this is where you start.  If you want only to learn some jargon and half explained, complex ideas, there are plenty of other sources.  If you can get 11th grade physics under your belt, quite a lot of the world will seem less mysterious to you, and you will be somewhat better prepared for the more complex ideas.  People want to jump straight from ignorance to quantum mechanics and General Relativity.  No one has ever done that, not the greatest scientists, not Newton, not Einstein, not Feynman.  Everybody has to learn the background knowledge and technique.  This Crash Course Physics gives an accurate outline of the basic science that every physicist, chemist and engineer begins with.

James Cashman   Mr Cashman, why have other commenters on this series stated that the subject matter in these videos is precisely the same as they studied in British schools?  I live in the US, and I can assure you that the material in these videos is covered in high school physics in the US.  I have my high school textbook, that I studied from in 1971-72, in front of me.  Everything covered in the CC Physics videos is in that textbook, with the exception of the tiny bit of calculus used in these videos.  That use of basic calculus is standard in first year university physics classes.

+KappaW   A lot of this series is at the level commonly taught in a decent high school physics class.  Some is from 1st year college physics.  The pressure, temperature behavior of gases usually gets a bit more coverage in high school and 1st year college chemistry.
+KappaW   The kinetic theory of gases including the ideal gas law was in my high school chemistry class in 1970.  Phase changes were also in that class.
+Mark Holm   It was the basic chemistry class not advanced.  It was the standard class in the curriculum, usually taken by sophomores or juniors.

+KappaW   Gas Laws, Kinetic Molecular Theory and Thermodynamics are all listed as basic subjects in the American Chemical Society's standards for high school chemistry.   https://www.acs.org/content/dam/acsorg/education/policies/recommendations-for-the-teaching-of-high-school-chemistry.pdf

+KappaW   You are not making any sense.  You made a statement that is patently false.  I corrected it and supplied evidence.  You respond with gibberish.  If you want me or anyone else to take you seriously you need to write something sensible about the subject.

+KappaW   The plain fact is that Dr Somara's subject matter so far is largely contained in standard high school chemistry and physics curricula, with some additions from 1st year college physics.  I am speaking primarily of high school and college chemistry and physics as I encountered them in the 1970s.  I am not speaking of AP level chemistry or physics.  Those classes did not exist when I was in high school.  Since I earned a bachelors degree in chemistry, and took some mid level college physics classes, I am also aware of the contents of higher level undergraduate classes.  Dr Somara has not ventured into those areas.  The material she has presented is not near the level of junior or senior year college classes.

The problem isn't that they're "dense," but that this isn't really intended to be a solid go-to replacement for actual instruction/study. It's in the name "CrashCourse."  I'm not even certain why you thought physics was a topic for the, "average person on the internet" piddling around on YouTube. If I think CrashCourse made any mistake in introducing the series it's only that a thorough mathematics course (that most people would ignore anyway) didn't accompany it, which as they say above, they have ideas about going forward with.  If you want an easy physics course? You'll need at minimum precalc and decent instruction/a good book on algebra-based physics. If you just want to skip all the math, you can do that and just listen, but physics - even with minimal prerequisites - requires a solid understanding of mathematical concepts. Anything less and we're basically back to making baking soda volcanoes and foam ball solar systems.

I have a good friend who started college thinking he wanted to be a chemical engineer.  Really threw himself into it.  But, he took some biology classes and found he was even more interested in that.  After a couple of years of Chem Eng, he decided to switch to PreMed.  His Chem Eng prof gave him Hell for it, but he switched anyway.  Now he is in his fourth decade as a physician, specializing in Nephrology.  He is also a Full Professor at a major medical school.  He still swears his introduction to chemical engineering was the best possible background for studying kidneys.  There is just too damn much chemical dynamics going on in them!
In my opinion, it's very well done. I'm 16 years old and I learned more and better here than in my school.
